Sino-Russian International Joint Laboratory for Clean Energy and Energy Conversion Technology College of Physics Jilin University Changchun 130012 Jilin China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Boosting potassium-ion storage by nitrogen/sulphur dual-doped hierarchical carbonaceous fibers derived from Aspergillus niger with large interlayer spacing, abundant defects and storage sites. The carbon materials as anode electrodes have been widely studied for potassium ion batteries (PIBs). However, the large size of potassium ions prevents their intercalation/deintercalation, resulting in poor storage behaviors. Herein, a novel design of N/S codoped hierarchical carbonaceous fibers (NSHCF) formed from nanosheets self-assembled by catalyzing Aspergillus niger with Sn is reported. The as-prepared NSHCF at 600 °C (NSHCF-600) exhibits a high reversible capacity of 345.4 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 after 100 cycles and an excellent rate performance of 124.5 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1. The excellent potassium storage performance can be ascribed to the N/S dual-doping, which enlarges interlayer spacing (0.404 nm) and introduces more defects. The larger interlayer spacing and higher pyridinic N active sites can promote K ions diffusion and storage. In addition, the ex situ transmission electron microscopy reveals the high reversibility of potassiation/depotassiation process and structural stability. Keywords Carbonaceous fibers Large interlayer spacing Nitrogen/sulphur dual-doping Potassium-ion batteries 1 Introduction Nowadays, energy shortage have become major social issue and spurred the development of lithium-ion batteries [1]. The demand for lithium ion batteries (LIBs) is increasing due to the rapid development of portable electronic devices. However, the reduction of lithium resources leads to the increase of cost. Thus, the new-type rechargeable battery systems are being urgently demanded as alternatives of LIBs [2–5]. PIBs as promising candidates have gained extensive attention due to the more abundant reserves of potassium comparing with lithium in the earth's crust [6–13]. Moreover, PIBs show lower redox potential of K+/K (−2.93 V) compared to that of Na+/Na (−2.71 V) and closer to that of Li+/Li (−3.04 V) vs. standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) [14–19], which ensures a high working voltage and energy density [20]. PIBs exhibit a similar working mechanism to lithium ion batteries. However, the large size of K ion (1.38 Å) compared to Li ion (0.76 Å) and Na ion (1.02 Å) is the primary limiting factor in development of PIBs [21–23]. Thus, it is still an enormous challenge to find suitable electrodes to expedite the extraction/insertion of K ions. At present, carbonaceous materials (i.e., graphite, graphene, hard carbon, soft carbon) as promising anode materials for PIBs have been widely reported [12,13,24–26]. However, these reported materials exhibit unsatisfying reversible capacities at low current densities, together with unfavorable cycling stability and rate capacity due to the poor diffusion kinetics for the intercalation and deintercalation of K ions. Furthermore, the maximum theoretical capacity of KC8 is only 279 mAh g−1 lower than that for LIBs [27]. Doping heteroatoms have been evaluated as an efficient method to boost the storage capability due to the introduced defect sites. Specifically, N-doped carbonaceous anode materials exhibit more active sites and optimized electronic structure, which enhance the adsorption and transfer of K ions [5,9,28–30]. Moreover, the interlayer space can be expanded by N doping, thereby delivering an easiest insertion and extraction of K ions, enhancing the storage performance. Compared with the N doping, S-doping can further expand the layer spacing due to the larger size of S atomic, produce defect structure and introduce more active sites [31]. Inspired by this, the synergistic effect of N doping and S doping is more favorable for the K+ adsorption ability. Most S doped materials are obtained by pyrolyzing S-containing materials or via pyrolysis reaction under Ar/H2S atmosphere. However, these methods are complex and not safe. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a new S doping method. On the other hand, the design and engineering of carbonaceous materials have been proved to be another effective strategy to improve the structural stability during cycling. For example, low-dimensional structure assembled by hierarchical nanostructure can intergrate the strengths of one-dimensional (1D) structure with those of hierarchical structure. Although applying these strategies can provide more active sites and more contact areas between electrode and electrolyte, finding an appropriate method to design a desirabale morphology while employing heteroatom doping is still challenging. Herein, we develop a facile and new strategy to design nitrogen and sulphur codoped hierarchical carbonaceous fibers (denoted as NSHCF), whereby Sn catalyze the homogeneous distribution and growth of graphene nanostructures derived from Aspergillus niger, which contains an abundant amount of natural nitrogen. Therefore, high quality N and defects can be generated in situ by adjusting the carbonization temperature through pyrolysis. In addation, S atoms are introduced by the adsorption and integration of Sn4+ and S2- by Aspergillus niger. This fascinating biological strategy is facile and nontoxic for stabilizing of S atoms. As expected, NSHCF-600 exhibits a higher amount of N/S and a larger interlayer spacing (0.404 nm) owing to the rich N/S-doping. The interlayer spacing of NSHCF-600 shows only a little change at full potassiation and depotassiation. Indeed, 1D porous carbonaceous fibers with hierarchical nanosheets can promote the diffusion of K ions. These characteristics make NSHCF-600 an excellent anode material for PIBs with high capacity, outstanding cycling performance and superb rate capability. Moreover, the K ions insertion/extraction mechanism and structural evolution are further studied through ex situ transmission electron microscope (TEM). This work may provide a new approach to design carbonaceous materials with specific architectures for high-performance PIBs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of NSHCF Aspergillus niger was firstly synthesized by oscillating culture. The spores of Aspergillus niger were mixed with 10 g glucose, 8 g peptone and 500 mL deionized water and cultured in an oscillation incubator for 3 days at 35 °C. Afterwards, the obtained Aspergillus niger was soaked in 300 mL ethanol solution of 0.1 M SnCl4·5H2O and 0.1 M CH3CSNH2 for 3 days at 35 °C. Then, the products were washed with ethanol solution and freeze-dried at −80 °C in vacuum, whereafter the precursors were carbonized at 500, 600 and 700 °C. The samples were washed with 1 M HCl and deionized water. The dried products were denoted as NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600 and NSHCF-700, respectively. 2.2 Material characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Magellan 400) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JSM–2010F) were conducted to investigate the morphology and microstructure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (VG ESCALAB MK II electron spectrometer) and powder diffractometer (RIGAKU, D/MAX 2550V) were used to analyze the elemental composition and crystalline phase. Raman spectra were obtained by Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw), using a 514.5 nm laser excitation and Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were characterized by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET, Beijing JW–BK132F). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The cells (CR2032) was assembled in an Ar-glovebox to test storage performance. 80% active material, 10% acetylene black, and 10% polyvinylidene difluoride were dissolved in N-methylpyrrolidone solvent to form homogeneous slurry and coated on a Cu foil. The average mass loading of working electrodes was about 1 mg cm−2. Whatman glass fiber (GF/D) and 0.8 M KPF6 solution dissolved in ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate were employed as the separator and electrolyte, respectively. Potassium foils were used as the counter electrodes, and the discharge–charge cycling tests were performed on a LAND CT2001A system. The CV and EIS tests were carried out using electrochemical workstation (IVIUM, Netherlands). 3 Results and discussion The NSHCF was synthesized using Aspergillus niger (Fig. S1a) as 1D biotemplate and nitrogen/carbon sources. As shown in Fig. 1 , Aspergillus niger was firstly prepared by shake culture. Then, the obtained Aspergillus niger absorbs Sn4+ and S2− ions via bioleaching strategy and eventually forms Sn/Aspergillus niger (Fig. S1b). In the process, S2− is released from the TAA, the Sn4+ and S2− ions were combined with −OH groups in chitin of Aspergillus niger. Afterwards, the precursors were carbonized at different temperatures in an Ar atmosphere to form SnS/NSHCF. During the carbonization process, SnS2 nanosheet is formed first and then the coated chitin is transformed into carbon nanosheet with the generation of SnS2 nanosheet, but SnS2 is unstable and Sx will dissociate from SnS2, so SnS2 is transformed into SnS [32]. At the same time, some of the Sn4+ is reduced to Sn by the carbon. The Sn inside the carbon nanosheet serves as graphitization catalyst [33]. Graphene structure is generated on the surface of Sn. Finally, NSHCF were obtained by removing Sn and SnS after acid treatment. As illustrated in Figs. 2 (a) and S2(a), the series of characteristic peaks in the XRD pattern of SnS/NSHCF can be assigned to the crystalline phase of SnS (JCPDS: 04-1750). After the acid washing, a broad diffraction peak at 21.7° corresponds to the (002) plane of NSHCF-600. Indeed, the interlayer distance of NSHCF-600 is 0.404 nm according to the Bragg equation, which is more conducive to the inserting of K ions compared to that of graphite (i.e., 0.335 nm). Notably, similar diffraction peaks are also observed for NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700 (Fig. S2b). Moreover, the crystallinity increases with the increase of temperature. To investigate the chemical state of N, S, C, O and Sn atoms in SnS/NSHCF and NSHCF, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted. The XPS survey spectrum of SnS/NSHCF and NSHCF are shown in Fig. S3. The N, S, C, O and Sn can be observed in XPS survey spectrum of SnS/NSHCF (Fig S3a and Table S1). After acid washing, the Sn is removed from the SnS/NSHCF (Fig. S3b and Table S2). The S 2p spectrum of NSHCF shows two peaks at 163.9 and 165.1 eV, corresponding to the C–S bond, and the characteristic peaks at 168.0 and 169.0 eV can be attributed to the oxidized sulfur (Figs. 2b and S4a, b) [34]. For the high-resolution C 1s spectrum, three peaks at 284.3, 284.7 and 285.6 eV correspond to the C–C, C–S and C=N bonds, respectively (Fig. S5a–c) [35,36]. According to the previous researches, the pyridinic N (N-6) can introduce more defects and active sites, boosting potassium–ion storage [28]. Thus, N 1s spectra of NSHCF were further investigated. As shown in Fig. 2(c), the N 1 s spectra consist of pyridinic N (N-6, 398.9 eV), pyrrolic N (N-5, 400.8 eV) and graphitic N (N-Q, 401.9 eV) [37,38]. The proportion of N-6 is 42.7%, 51.7%, and 41.5% for NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600, and NSHCF-700, respectively. According to the Tables S1 and S2, obviously, the element content of S and N greatly reduces at higher temperature. Because NSHCF-600 exhibits the highest content of pyridinic N and S, it is more favorable for enhancement of the electrochemical performance. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy measurements were performed to characterize the structure of NSHCF. As shown in Fig. 2(d), the D-band (1350 cm−1) and G-band (1569 cm−1) represent the vibration of defective carbon and graphitic carbon [11,39]. The relative intensity ratio of I D/I G is used to evaluate the disorder degree in carbon. The value of this ratio is 1.08 in NSHCF-600, which is higher than that in NSHCF-500 (1.01) and NSHCF-700 (0.98), indicating a higher defective structure due to the N/S-doping. As a supplementary assessment, the surface areas and pores size distributions were measured (Fig. S6). The specific surface areas in NSHCF-500, −600 and −700 are 234.63, 296.58, and 283.07 m2 g−1, respectively (Fig. S6a). The isotherm curves of all samples display a typical type IV adsorption isotherm, demonstrating that NSHCF primarily contains micropores and mesopores. The pores size distributions are also shown in Fig. S6(b). According to the above results, NSHCF-600 with the highest content of N/S and specific surface area can be considered as a promising electrode material for PIBs. To further illustrate the structure of NSHCF-600, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were conducted [40]. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), SnS/NSHCF-600 reveals a 1D fibrous structure and the amplified SEM image evidently shows that the fibers are constituted by nanosheets architecture (inset in Fig. 3a), which is further validated by the scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image in Fig. 3(b). Meanwhile, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) images display lattice fringes of 0.284 and 0.342 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (201) planes of SnS (Fig. 3c, d). In addition, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) also confirms the crystallinity of SnS (inset in Fig. 3d). The EDS mapping (Fig. 3e) analysis demonstrates that the C, N, S, and Sn are uniformly spread along the fibers and the element contents are shown in Table S3. After acid washing, NSHCF-600 still maintains the fiber structure (Fig. 3f). Indeed, the nanosheet structure can be observed more clearly in the STEM image (Figs. 3g and S7), which proves that SnS has been removed. For detailed analysis of NSHCF-600, HRTEM and IFFT were employed as depicted in Fig. 3(h), in which NSHCF-600 shows discontinuous graphite fringes in some areas due to the catalysis of Sn [33], providing more active sites for K-ions storage. The expanded interlayer distance of NSHCF-600 is 0.403–0.408 nm, which can facilitate the intercalation of K ions. The larger interlayer space of NSHCF-600 can be attributed to the N/S-doping which optimizes the electronic structure to a great extent. The EDS mapping results in Fig. 3(i) also verify that N and S are homogeneously distributed in the fibers. The element contents analysis of samples also proves that when the carbonization temperature reaches a certain level, the content of N and S decreases (Tables S3 and S4). Based on the mapping and element content analysis, the S element still exists in the fiber at a high content even after acid washing, which again proves the advantage of Aspergillus niger in S fixation by the biological method. For comparison, the characterization of NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700 is displayed in Fig. S8. As shown in Fig. S8(c, f), the average lattice spacing of NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700 is about 0.405 and 0.403 nm which is close to the NSHCF-600. NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600 and NSHCF-700 have almost the same lattice spacing, but the lattice areas are different due to the difference of content of N and S. The NSHCF-600 exhibits the highest content of N and S and has more lattice areas than NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700. The K-ions storage performance of NSHCF was tested in half cells. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of NSHCF-600 for the first 4 cycles at 0.2 mV s−1 are shown in Fig. 4 (a), in which the broad cathodic peak below 1 V can be ascribed to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films, while the peak at around 0.01 V should be caused by the intercalation of K ions into NSHCF-600 [41]. The subsequent CV curves are nearly overlapped, suggesting reversible electrode reactions and good cycling stability. Fig. 4(b) shows the charge–discharge curves of NSHCF-600, in which the sloping discharge curves are consistent with the previous reports of carbonaceous materials. The initial discharge and charge capacities of NSHCF-600 are 913.0 and 465.9 mAh g−1, respectively, and the low coulombic efficiency (CE) of 51.0% can be attributed to the high specific surface area, which leads to the formation of massive SEI layers. The cycling performance of NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600, and NSHCF-700 is shown in Fig. 4(c). NSHCF-600 exhibits a high capacity retention of 345.4 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 after 100 cycles, while NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700 deliver lower specific capacity of 98.3 and 201.1 mAh g−1, respectively. Furthermore, the CE gradually increases to 99% after first 20 cycles. Fig. 4(d) shows the rate performance of the three samples, in which NSHCF-600 delivers high reversible capacities of 416.2, 314.4, 212, 164.7, and 124.5 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 A g−1, respectively. When the current density decreases back to 0.1 A g−1, the capacity can still be maintained at 392.6 mAh g−1, which is much higher than those of NSHCF-500 (158.7 mAh g−1) and NSHCF-700 (217.2 mAh g−1). The excellent storage performance of NSHCF-600 is superior to the reported carbonaceous anodes for PIBs (Table S5). The long-term cycling stability of NSHCF-600 is also shown in Fig. 4(e), in which NSHCF-600 can show an impressive capacity of 179.3 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 A g−1. The high K-ions storage performance of NSHCF-600 is ascribed to these reasons. Firstly, the high surface defects resulted from in situ N-doping accelerate adsorption and diffusion rate of K ion. Secondly, the interlayer spacing can be further expanded to 0.404 nm by S doping which enhances K ion intercalation and reduces volume expansion. Thirdly, the combination of N doping and S doping optimizes the electronic structure, enhancing the K ion adsorption. To investigate the potassium-ion storage behavior, CV tests were performed at varying sweep rates from 0.4 to 2 mV s−1 (Fig. 5 a–c). The CV curves show that the broad anodic peak increases and expands towards high potential with the increase of sweep rates, indicating a surface-dominated characteristic. The reaction mechanisms are determined by the equation of log i = b·log v + log a, where i and v represent peak current and scan rate, respectively, a and b are constants. The b-value can be obtained by calculating the slope of log(i)–log(v) curves. Generally, a b-value close to 1 is indicative of capacitive behavior (surface-driven behavior), while that close to 0.5 signifies a diffusion-controlled process [12,28,42]. In this work, the b-value is respectively 0.63, 0.80 and 0.77 for NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600 and NSHCF-700, demonstrating a mixed behavior of capacitive and diffusion-controlled process (Fig. 5d). The contribution can be distinguished by the equation i ( v ) = k 1·v + k 2·v 1/2, where k 1·v and k 2·v 1/2 stand for the surface-driven behavior and diffusion-controlled process, respectively [17,43,44]. The capacitance contribution ratios of NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600 and NSHCF-700 are shown in Fig. 5(e–h). As expected, the surface capacitive process ratio of NSHCF-600 is much higher than those of NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700 at all sweep rates, and gradually increases from 52.1% to 83% with the increase of scanning rate. To further analyze the reaction kinetics of the three samples, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were conducted. The results are fitted by equivalent circuit (Fig. S9) and shown in Fig. 5(i). The charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of NSHCF-600 in the high frequency region is smaller compared with those of NSHCF-500 and NSHCF-700. Furthermore, the diffusion coefficient of the K ions (D K) are calculated from the EIS results by the equation D k = 0.5R 2 T 3/A 2 n 4 F 4 C 2 σ 2 (σ = dZ/dω −1/2) [19,45,46]. As shown in Fig S10, the D k value of NSHCF-500, NSHCF-600, and NSHCF-700 is 1.63 × 10−13, 3.55 × 10−13, and 2.03 × 10−13 cm2 s−1, respectively. NSHCF-600 displays the highest D k value which is indicative of faster K+ diffusion rate, thereby improving the rate capability of NSHCF-600. Ex situ TEM was further employed to investigate the storage mechanism. According to Fig. 6 (a, b), which show the STEM and EDS mappings of NSHCF-600 after full potassiation, NSHCF-600 reveals a stable fibrous structure and C, N, S, and K are uniformly distributed along the fiber. After full depotassiation, the structure and elements distribution recover to the original state (Figs. S11 and 6c). The pristine NSHCF-600 exhibits expanded interlayer spacing of 0.404 nm on average (Fig. 6d, g). With K-ions intercalation, the interlayer spacing increases to 0.425 nm, suggesting that the K ions successfully intercalate into NSHCF-600 (Fig. 6e, h). Remarkably, a more ordered graphite structure is observed after full potassiation. After extraction of K ions (Fig. 6f, i), the ordered interlayer distance (0.407 nm) shows a slight change compared to the original structure, indicating the excellent reversibility of NSHCF-600. Based on the above analysis, the layered structure of NSHCF-600 can efficiently accommodate the change of interlayer distance upon potassiation/depotassiation, realizing superior K-ions storage performance 4 Conclusions In summary, NSHCF-600 with high defective microcrystal stripes was prepared via catalysis between Sn and Aspergillus niger with N/S dual-doping. Benefiting from the expanding interlayer spacing, abundant defects and more storage sites, resulted from the hierarchical structure and high pyridinic N/S dual-doping, NSHCF-600 delivers a high reversible specific capacity of 345.4 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 after 100 cycles and an excellent rate performance of 124.5 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1. Kinetics analysis reveals that NSHCF-600 exhibits higher capacitive contribution and K+ diffusion coefficient. Furthermore, the study results of ex situ TEM indicate that the hierarchical structure of NSHCF-600 possesses a high reversibility and can perfectly accommodate the change of interlayer spacing during potassiation and depotassiation. More importantly, this work opens a new way to design novel carbonaceous anode materials with ordered highly defective structure for boosting PIBs. coredata.dc:description: The carbon materials as anode electrodes have been widely studied for potassium ion batteries (PIBs). However, the large size of potassium ions prevents their intercalation/deintercalation, resulting in poor storage behaviors. Herein, a novel design of N/S codoped hierarchical carbonaceous fibers (NSHCF) formed from nanosheets self-assembled by catalyzing Aspergillus niger with Sn is reported. The as-prepared NSHCF at 600 °C (NSHCF-600) exhibits a high reversible capacity of 345.4 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 after 100 cycles and an excellent rate performance of 124.5 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1. The excellent potassium storage performance can be ascribed to the N/S dual-doping, which enlarges interlayer spacing (0.404 nm) and introduces more defects. The larger interlayer spacing and higher pyridinic N active sites can promote K ions diffusion and storage. In addition, the ex situ transmission electron microscopy reveals the high reversibility of potassiation/depotassiation process and structural stability.
